video.title: Full stack Python Flask tutorial - Build a social network
video.description:
Learn how to build a basic social platform with the Python Flask web framework. In this video we review how to create a database, pull data in and out of that database, create a web server with python, and use python HTML templating to render a page for the user!

Tutorial created by John G. Fisher. Watch more great tutorial from John on his YouTube channel:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCoMAKPDECRWb7GEWF1lQZMQ

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Ramkrishna Bihani
topLevelComment.text:
@John G. Fisher   Unable to execute sqlite3 database.db < schema.sql. Using powershell on win10. The error that I get, "The term 'sqlite3' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program"; while with cmd the error that I get is "'sqlite3' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.". Does sqlite3 not come preinstalled with Python?

replies.author: Asim Junaid
replies.text:
download sqlite3 from their official website and add the path in environment variables.
OR
create a random file named let's say 'generate-database.db'
and copy the code below 
import sqlite3

conn = sqlite3.connect('database.db')
c = conn.cursor()

c.execute('''

create table posts(
id integer primary key autoincrement,
name text not null,
content text not null);
          ''')

conn.commit()
conn.close()

You can delete this file after the database is created. Hope this helps !

topLevelComment.author: Joe LoMoglio
topLevelComment.text: This is far from a Social network, its nothing more than a very very basic blog app. So its very misleading and was a waste of my time. Your not very organized in your thoughts, so anyone who is new to Python and Flask, I recommend the blog tutorial by Traversy Media, Brad does a much better job at explaining things in depth. This video is way to short to really provide enough knowledge. If its intent was just a code along then great, but not a useful tutorial as it lacks many things that a noob would need to know.  Disclaimer, I have no affiliation to Traversy Media, just think that his video series is better suited to someone new to Flask.

topLevelComment.author: Overfeed Web Agency
topLevelComment.text:
Copyright and Intellectual Property, CONSULTATION

Hello, I would like to know, IF YOU HAD A Social Network, how do you handle the Copyright within your Social NETWORD platform. This is a very sensitive issue, for example if a user wishes to post an article of the Toyota brand. And the toyota company verifies that a user of you within your website is using your name and brand logo to make positive or negative comments about your brand.
How do you control that?

Another example if a user makes a bad comment about a tennis player and the tennis player demands you, for publishing that bad comment.
How would you handle that issue?

Would it be interesting to me to answer those two examples as you would handle that?

That depends on what type of programming you want to do. If you are interested in becoming a full stack web developer, you should check out the free curriculum at www.freecodecamp.org.
If you want to learn Python, start with this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfscVS0vtbw

Looking forward to know more about the usage of additional python libraries to make medium and complex Python projects. Thanks for your efforts in putting everything together.

topLevelComment.author: Andrew Wilmot

topLevelComment.author: Mr Valdes
topLevelComment.text: Should've used sqlalchemy and a more robust db imo.

replies.author: Danbo
replies.text: Yes, also you can't really call this a social network, sessions are missing, users are missing, validation, access control, security, etc. If you are going to build a mini social media you can do it in Flask but as it grows it would be wiser to switch to a framework  like Django, Rails, Laravel or one of the node libraries. Personally I'm exploring the path of doing my front in React and backend using Rails or Express and GraphQL to make API calls dead simple.

replies.author: Mr Valdes
replies.text: @Danbo yeah just dont think its a good idea to show people how to build your own Facebook with raw SQL lol

replies.author: Danbo
replies.text: Agree with the ORM but SQLight is fine for small projects like this it scales good enough up to 1 million records but using the ORM you can use any DB

replies.author: John G. Fisher
replies.text: Agreed, decided ORM was beyond the scope of the video.
